name: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)
summary: A non-invasive brain stimulation technique that uses magnetic fields to modulate neural activity, FDA-approved for depression, OCD, and migraine prevention.
description: Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) is a non-invasive neuromodulation technique that delivers focused magnetic pulses to specific brain regions, most commonly the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Repetitive TMS (rTMS) can alter cortical excitability and functional connectivity, making it a well-established treatment for major depressive disorder and OCD. TMS is generally safe, performed in outpatient settings, and requires no anesthesia. Variants include intermittent theta burst stimulation (iTBS) and deep TMS (dTMS), which target different brain regions and reduce treatment time.

contraindications: Metallic implants near the head (e.g., aneurysm clips, cochlear implants)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Well tolerated. Common side effects include headache, scalp discomfort, and transient fatigue. Rare risk of seizure.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: High for depression and OCD; moderate for other conditions.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Hundreds of RCTs and meta-analyses support efficacy for depression; expanding evidence for other disorders.

sections.text: TMS delivers rapidly changing magnetic fields via a coil placed on the scalp. These fields induce electric currents in cortical neurons, modulating excitability and network activity. Repetitive TMS (rTMS) can produce lasting changes in synaptic plasticity, resembling mechanisms of learning and memory.

sections.preparation: Patient seated in a chair; no anesthesia required.
procedure: Magnetic coil placed over the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex or other target.
Stimulation intensity determined by motor threshold.
sections.duration: 20–40 minutes per session; 3–6 weeks total treatment course.

long_term: Functional improvements in mood and cognition

ideal_candidates: OCD patients who have not responded to medication/therapy

facility: Specialized clinics or hospital-based TMS suites

studies: Large RCTs demonstrate efficacy of TMS for treatment-resistant depression.
Deep TMS approved for OCD with supportive clinical trial data.
Theta-burst TMS validated as non-inferior to standard protocols for depression.
sections.limitations: Response varies across individuals; durability of benefit may require maintenance sessions.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered for treatment-resistant depression; coverage expanding for OCD.
sections.cost_effectiveness: High when successful, reducing long-term medication and hospitalization costs.

sections.pediatric: Investigational; some trials in adolescents with depression.
sections.elderly: Safe and effective; may respond more slowly.
sections.pregnancy: Appears safe, though more studies needed.
sections.comorbidities: Caution in patients with seizure disorders or implanted devices.

items: FDA-approved for depression, OCD, and migraine prevention.
Theta-burst TMS offers faster sessions with comparable efficacy.
Maintenance TMS may be needed to prevent relapse.
